1.verse_text: The most beautiful of songs, by Solomon. your love is better than wine. the sound of your name recalls it. No woman could keep from loving you. be my king and take me to your room. We will be happy together, drink deep, and lose ourselves in love. No wonder all women love you! dark as the desert tents of Kedar, but beautiful as the draperies in Solomon's palace. because the sun has tanned me. My brothers were angry with me and made me work in the vineyard. I had no time to care for myself. Where will you lead your flock to graze? Where will they rest from the noonday sun? Why should I need to look for you Go and follow the flock; find pasture for your goats near the tents of the shepherds. as a mare excites the stallions of Pharaoh's chariots. and falls along your neck like jewels. with ornaments of silver. and my perfume filled the air with fragrance. as he lies upon my breasts. that bloom in the vineyards at Engedi. how your eyes shine with love! how you delight me! The green grass will be our bed; and the cypress trees the ceiling.
Your lips cover me with kisses;
There is a fragrance about you;
Take me with you, and we'll run away;
Women of Jerusalem, I am dark but beautiful,
Don't look down on me because of my color,
Tell me, my love, among the flocks of the other shepherds?
Don't you know the place, loveliest of women?
Your hair is beautiful upon your cheeks
But we will make for you a chain of gold
My king was lying on his couch,
My lover has the scent of myrrh
My lover is like the wild flowers
How beautiful you are, my love;
How handsome you are, my dearest;
the cedars will be the beams of our house,

2.verse_text: I am only a wild flower in Sharon, a lily in a mountain valley. is my darling among women. so is my dearest compared to other men. I love to sit in its shadow, and its fruit is sweet to my taste. and raised the banner of love over me. and refresh me with apples! I am weak from passion. and his right hand caresses me. swear by the swift deer and the gazelles that you will not interrupt our love. He comes running over the mountains, racing across the hills to me. like a young stag. There he stands beside the wall. He looks in through the window and glances through the lattice. Come then, my love; my darling, come with me. This is the time for singing; the song of doves is heard in the fields. the air is fragrant with blossoming vines. Come then, my love; my darling, come with me. in the crevice of a rock. Let me see your lovely face and hear your enchanting voice. before they ruin our vineyard in bloom. He feeds his flock among the lilies and the darkness disappears. Return, my darling, like a gazelle,
Like an apple tree among the trees of the forest,
He brought me to his banquet hall
His left hand is under my head,
My lover is like a gazelle,
The winter is over; the rains have stopped;
in the countryside the flowers are in bloom.
You are like a dove that hides
Catch the foxes, the little foxes,
My lover is mine, and I am his.
until the morning breezes blow like a stag on the mountains of Bether.

3.verse_text: Asleep on my bed, night after night I dreamed of the one I love; I was looking for him, but couldn't find him. through its streets and alleys. I looked for the one I love. I looked, but couldn't find him. I asked them, 'Have you found my lover?' I held him and wouldn't let him go until I took him to my mother's house, to the room where I was born. swear by the swift deer and the gazelles that you will not interrupt our love. fragrant with incense and myrrh, the incense sold by the traders? sixty soldiers form the bodyguard, the finest soldiers in Israel. they are battle-hardened veterans. Each of them is armed with a sword, on guard against a night attack. made of the finest wood. over it is cloth embroidered with gold. Its cushions are covered with purple cloth, lovingly woven by the women of Jerusalem. He is wearing the crown that his mother placed on his head on his wedding day, on the day of his gladness and joy.
I went wandering through the city,
The sentries patrolling the city saw me.
As soon as I left them, I found him.
What is this coming from the desert like a column of smoke,
Solomon is coming, carried on his throne;
All of them are skillful with the sword;
King Solomon is carried on a throne
Its posts are covered with silver;
Women of Zion, come and see King Solomon.

4.verse_text: How beautiful you are, my love! How your eyes shine with love behind your veil. Your hair dances like a flock of goats bounding down the hills of Gilead. that have just been shorn and washed. Not one of them is missing; they are all perfectly matched. how lovely they are when you speak. Your cheeks glow behind your veil. with a necklace like a thousand shields hung around it. twin deer feeding among lilies. the hill of incense, until the morning breezes blow and the darkness disappears. how perfect you are! come with me from Lebanon. Come down from the top of Mount Amana, from Mount Senir and Mount Hermon, where the lions and leopards live. and the necklace you are wearing have stolen my heart. my sweetheart and bride. Your love is better than wine; your perfume more fragrant than any spice. your tongue is milk and honey for me. Your clothing has all the fragrance of Lebanon. a walled garden, a private spring; They grow like an orchard of pomegranate trees and bear the finest fruits. There is no lack of henna and nard, or incense of every kind. Myrrh and aloes grow there with all the most fragrant perfumes. streams of flowing water, brooks gushing down from the Lebanon Mountains. South Wind, blow on my garden; fill the air with fragrance. Let my lover come to his garden and eat the best of its fruits.
Your teeth are as white as sheep
Your lips are like a scarlet ribbon;
Your neck is like the tower of David, round and smooth,
I will stay on the hill of myrrh,
How beautiful you are, my love;
Come with me from the Lebanon Mountains, my bride;
The look in your eyes, my sweetheart and bride,
The taste of honey is on your lips, my darling;
My sweetheart, my bride, is a secret garden,

5.verse_text: I have entered my garden, my sweetheart, my bride. I am gathering my spices and myrrh; I am eating my honey and honeycomb; I am drinking my wine and milk. Eat, lovers, and drink until you are drunk with love! I dreamed my lover knocked at the door. Let me come in, my darling, my sweetheart, my dove. My head is wet with dew, and my hair is damp from the mist. why should I get dressed again? I have washed my feet; why should I get them dirty again? and I was thrilled that he was near. My hands were covered with myrrh, my fingers with liquid myrrh, as I grasped the handle of the door. but he had already gone. How I wanted to hear his voice! I looked for him, but couldn't find him; I called to him, but heard no answer. they struck me and bruised me; the guards at the city wall tore off my cape. that if you find my lover, you will tell him I am weak from passion. is your lover different from everyone else? What is there so wonderful about him that we should give you our promise? he is one in ten thousand. his hair is wavy, black as a raven. that is full of herbs and spices. His lips are like lilies, wet with liquid myrrh. and he wears rings set with gems. with sapphires set in it. set in sockets of gold. He is majestic, like the Lebanon Mountains with their towering cedars. everything about him enchants me. This is what my lover is like, women of Jerusalem.
While I slept, my heart was awake.
My lover put his hand to the door,
I was ready to let him come in.
I opened the door for my lover,
The sentries patrolling the city found me;
My lover is handsome and strong;
His face is bronzed and smooth;
His eyes are as beautiful as doves by a flowing brook, doves washed in milk and standing by the stream. His body is like smooth ivory,
His cheeks are as lovely as a garden
His thighs are columns of alabaster
His mouth is sweet to kiss;

6.verse_text: Most beautiful of women, where has your lover gone? Tell us which way your lover went, so that we can help you find him. where the balsam trees grow. He is feeding his flock in the garden and gathering lilies. he feeds his flock among the lilies. as lovely as the city of Tirzah, they are holding me captive. Your hair dances like a flock of goats bounding down the hills of Gilead. that have just been washed. Not one of them is missing; they are all perfectly matched. young women without number! and she is as lovely as a dove. She is her mother's only daughter, her mother's favorite child. All women look at her and praise her; queens and concubines sing her praises. She is beautiful and bright, to see the young plants in the valley, to see the new leaves on the vines and the blossoms on the pomegranate trees. Let us watch you as you dance. Why do you want to watch me as I dance between the rows of onlookers?
My lover has gone to his garden,
My lover is mine, and I am his;
My love, you are as beautiful as Jerusalem, as breathtaking as these great cities. as dazzling as the sun or the moon. as a chariot driver is for battle.
Turn your eyes away from me;
Your teeth are as white as a flock of sheep
Your cheeks glow behind your veil.
Let the king have sixty queens, eighty concubines,
Who is this whose glance is like the dawn?
I have come down among the almond trees
I am trembling; you have made me as eager for love

7.verse_text: What a magnificent young woman you are! How beautiful are your feet in sandals. The curve of your thighs is like the work of an artist. that never runs out of spiced wine. A sheaf of wheat is there, surrounded by lilies. like two gazelles. Your eyes are like the pools in the city of Heshbon, near the gate of that great city. Your nose is as lovely as the tower of Lebanon that stands guard at Damascus. Your braided hair shines like the finest satin; how complete the delights of your love. and your breasts are clusters of dates. and pick its fruit. To me your breasts are like bunches of grapes, your breath like the fragrance of apples, Then let the wine flow straight to my lover, to see whether they've started to grow, whether the blossoms are opening and the pomegranate trees are in bloom. There I will give you my love. and all the pleasant fruits are near our door. Darling, I have kept for you the old delights and the new.
Your breasts are like twin deer,
Your neck is like a tower of ivory.
Your head is held high like Mount Carmel. its beauty could hold a king captive. flowing over his lips and teeth. and spend the night in the villages.
How pretty you are, how beautiful;
You are as graceful as a palm tree,
I will climb the palm tree
and your mouth like the finest wine.
I belong to my lover, and he desires me.
Come, darling, let's go out to the countryside
We will get up early and look at the vines
You can smell the scent of mandrakes,

8.verse_text: I wish that you were my brother, that my mother had nursed you at her breast. Then, if I met you in the street, I could kiss you and no one would mind. where you could teach me love. I would give you spiced wine, my pomegranate wine to drink. and your right hand caresses me. that you will not interrupt our love. arm in arm with her lover? Under the apple tree I woke you, in the place where you were born. hold no one in your arms but me. Love is as powerful as death; passion is as strong as death itself. It bursts into flame and burns like a raging fire. no flood can drown it. But if any tried to buy love with their wealth, contempt is all they would get. and her breasts are still small. What will we do for her when a young man comes courting? we will build her a silver tower. But if she is a gate, we will protect her with panels of cedar. and my breasts are its towers. My lover knows that with him I find contentment and peace. in a place called Baal Hamon. There are farmers who rent it from him; each one pays a thousand silver coins. and the farmers to two hundred as their share; I have a vineyard of my own! my companions are waiting to hear you speak. like a young stag on the mountains where spices grow.
I would take you to my mother's house,
Your left hand is under my head,
Who is this coming from the desert,
Close your heart to every love but mine;
Solomon is welcome to his thousand coins,
Let me hear your voice from the garden, my love;
Come to me, my lover, like a gazelle,

9.verse_text: In the beginning, when God created the universe,
the earth was formless and desolate. The raging ocean that covered everything was engulfed in total darkness, and the Spirit of God was moving over the water.
Then God commanded, 'Let there be light'–and light appeared.
God was pleased with what he saw. Then he separated the light from the darkness,
and he named the light 'Day' and the darkness 'Night.' Evening passed and morning came–that was the first day.
He named the dome 'Sky.' Evening passed and morning came–that was the second day.
Then God commanded, 'Let the water below the sky come together in one place, so that the land will appear'–and it was done.
He named the land 'Earth,' and the water which had come together he named 'Sea.' And God was pleased with what he saw.
Then he commanded, 'Let the earth produce all kinds of plants, those that bear grain and those that bear fruit'–and it was done.
So the earth produced all kinds of plants, and God was pleased with what he saw.
Evening passed and morning came–that was the third day.
Then God commanded, 'Let lights appear in the sky to separate day from night and to show the time when days, years, and religious festivals begin;
they will shine in the sky to give light to the earth'–and it was done.
So God made the two larger lights, the sun to rule over the day and the moon to rule over the night; he also made the stars.
He placed the lights in the sky to shine on the earth,
to rule over the day and the night, and to separate light from darkness. And God was pleased with what he saw.
Evening passed and morning came–that was the fourth day.
Then God commanded, 'Let the water be filled with many kinds of living beings, and let the air be filled with birds.'
So God created the great sea monsters, all kinds of creatures that live in the water, and all kinds of birds. And God was pleased with what he saw.
He blessed them all and told the creatures that live in the water to reproduce and to fill the sea, and he told the birds to increase in number.
Evening passed and morning came–that was the fifth day.
Then God commanded, 'Let the earth produce all kinds of animal life: domestic and wild, large and small'–and it was done.
So God made them all, and he was pleased with what he saw.
Then God said, 'And now we will make human beings; they will be like us and resemble us. They will have power over the fish, the birds, and all animals, domestic and wild, large and small.'
So God created human beings, making them to be like himself. He created them male and female,

blessed them, and said, 'Have many children, so that your descendants will live all over the earth and bring it under their control. I am putting you in charge of the fish, the birds, and all the wild animals.
I have provided all kinds of grain and all kinds of fruit for you to eat;
but for all the wild animals and for all the birds I have provided grass and leafy plants for food'–and it was done.
God looked at everything he had made, and he was very pleased. Evening passed and morning came–that was the sixth day.

but for all the wild animals and for all the birds I have provided grass and leafy plants for food'–and it was done.
